text: <@U01CVV30P18> I guess I misled you on this one, Party ID stays the same, only Participant ID changes (i.e. on the first setup Participant ID is used as a prefix for Party ID but after restoration Participant ID changes and doesn't match Party ID prefix anymore).

text:
How can I get package id from package name (`splice-amulet`) to be used in filtering /v1/updates by template_id?

ACS endpoint accepts `templates` as a filter where template is specified prefixed with package_name but /updates doesn't have such a filter so filtering has to be done post-response.
e.g. `"template_id": "511bd3bf23fab4e5171edb22dceabe3061f7faf78a44f8af44f3b87f977c61f6:Splice.Amulet:Amulet"`

elements.text: How can I get package id from package name (
splice-amulet

) to be used in filtering /v1/updates by template_id?

ACS endpoint accepts
templates

as a filter where template is specified prefixed with package_name but /updates doesn't have such a filter so filtering has to be done post-response.
e.g.
"template_id": "511bd3bf23fab4e5171edb22dceabe3061f7faf78a44f8af44f3b87f977c61f6:Splice.Amulet:Amulet"

text:
Yes, did you setup auth and are using auth0? if you setup auth and are trying to access wallet.localhost you are gonna have a bad time, you need to setup actual hostnames and tls and callbacks. or configure your callbacks to allow <http://wallet.localhost> and then use ssh port forwarding and login localhost with your oauth flow while having browser developer console open , inspect the request and grab your bearer token from there.

Once you have your bearer token you can use it in terminal with curl directly or docker exec -it into the container and use it while

```curl -v <http://localhost:5003/api/validator/v0/admin/participant/identities> -H "authorization: Bearer your-bearer-token```

elements.text: Yes, did you setup auth and are using auth0? if you setup auth and are trying to access wallet.localhost you are gonna have a bad time, you need to setup actual hostnames and tls and callbacks. or configure your callbacks to allow

and then use ssh port forwarding and login localhost with your oauth flow while having browser developer console open , inspect the request and grab your bearer token from there.

Once you have your bearer token you can use it in terminal with curl directly or docker exec -it into the container and use it while
curl -v
-H "authorization: Bearer your-bearer-token

text:
Can anyone help me see if I need to perform any other steps?

So far I have set up a devnet validator using docker compose, without auth. I was able to find 3 keypairs to backup:

```"keys":[{"keyPair":"KEY","name":"namespace"},{"keyPair":"KEY","name":"signing"},{"keyPair":"KEY","name":"encryption"}]```
Without any port opened in internet, I can't access the wallet UI. Should I be able to do that? Are there any operations I should perform there? Is there any other way to opeate our wallet?

Also, are there any available metrics or anything in particular I should look for in logs, to make sure everything works as expected?

elements.text:
Can anyone help me see if I need to perform any other steps?

"keys":[{"keyPair":"KEY","name":"namespace"},{"keyPair":"KEY","name":"signing"},{"keyPair":"KEY","name":"encryption"}]

Without any port opened in internet, I can't access the wallet UI. Should I be able to do that? Are there any operations I should perform there? Is there any other way to opeate our wallet?

Also, are there any available metrics or anything in particular I should look for in logs, to make sure everything works as expected?

text:
```ssh yourserverip -L 8080:localhost:80```
then on your local computer go in the browser to <http://wallet.localhost:8080> or localhost:8080 and you should be able to log in , for accessing the wallet outside of that you will need to setup TLS / authentication otherwise anyone will be able to get to the ui.

text: I do not currently have time but look into changing allowed callback urls to what would be accessible from your browser , ie probably <http://wallet.localhost/callback> and then things should work with the auth flow assuming you created a user in auth0 first and used their identity when running start.sh and also would need more information and logs from your browser / server to even begin to troubleshoot.

elements.text: I do not currently have time but look into changing allowed callback urls to what would be accessible from your browser , ie probably

and then things should work with the auth flow assuming you created a user in auth0 first and used their identity when running start.sh and also would need more information and logs from your browser / server to even begin to troubleshoot.

text:
This one right <@U04UQLMNXV1>?
```# Uncomment the following block if you want to restore from a participant dump
# and recover your balance
# PARTICIPANT_BOOTSTRAP_MIGRATE_TO_NEW_PARTICIPANT_START
  participantIdentitiesDumpImport:
    secretName: participant-bootstrap-dump
    # Make sure to also adjust nodeIdentifier to the same value
    newParticipantIdentifier: chata-dev-1-restore
  migrateValidatorParty: true
# PARTICIPANT_BOOTSTRAP_MIGRATE_TO_NEW_PARTICIPANT_END```

elements.text: This one right

# Uncomment the following block if you want to restore from a participant dump
# and recover your balance
# PARTICIPANT_BOOTSTRAP_MIGRATE_TO_NEW_PARTICIPANT_START
  participantIdentitiesDumpImport:
    secretName: participant-bootstrap-dump
    # Make sure to also adjust nodeIdentifier to the same value
    newParticipantIdentifier: chata-dev-1-restore
  migrateValidatorParty: true
# PARTICIPANT_BOOTSTRAP_MIGRATE_TO_NEW_PARTICIPANT_END

text:
Scenario:
• there is a validator
• there is identity dump
• validator is completely destroyed and restored from the identity dump so that participant id changes and party id stays the same
Question:
• if I destroy the validator again and try to recover from the same identity dump (which is from original validator and not from the restored one), would restoration work? And if so what needs to be done for restoration to work?

Question:

if I destroy the validator again and try to recover from the same identity dump (which is from original validator and not from the restored one), would restoration work? And if so what needs to be done for restoration to work?

text:
Everything worked. Thank you.

My idea about where the party was hosted was wrong which resulted in not being able do another recovery. I've got the correct participant id from API, used it as `id` in the identities dump and the recovery procedure worked.

Saving this for history
```# Destroy validator (compose-based)
./stop.sh
 docker volume rm splice-validator_domain-upgrade-dump splice-validator_postgres-splice

# Update identities dump
SCAN_URL=<https://scan.sv.dev.global.canton.network.sv-nodeops.com>
domain_id=global-domain::122071b3b1bdf69f2df3e161bd9933f2c419cdac3c48eaab7c2b920b6956d5d2a87b
party_id=stas-test-2025-05-09::122004320164ddaa20ea6d21e068d7884205ac762ed4dcd59bcc741259ac910af805
participant_id=$(curl -fsS "$SCAN_URL/api/scan/v0/domains/$domain_id/parties/$party_id/participant-id" | jq -r .participant_id)
cat /tmp/identities.json | jq --arg participant_id "$participant_id" '.id = $participant_id' > /tmp/identities.updated.json

# Recover
MIGRATION_ID=1
SPONSOR_SV_URL=<https://sv.sv.dev.global.canton.network.sv-nodeops.com>
SEQUENCER_URL=<https://sequencer-1.sv.dev.global.canton.network.sv-nodeops.com>
PARTY_HINT=stas-test-2025-05-09
NEW_PARTICIPANT_ID="$PARTY_HINT-8"
echo "Migrating $PARTY_HINT from $(echo "$participant_id" | awk -F :: '{print $2}') to $NEW_PARTICIPANT_ID"
./start.sh -s "$SPONSOR_SV_URL" -o "" -p "$PARTY_HINT" -m "$MIGRATION_ID" -w -bq "$SEQUENCER_URL" -P "$NEW_PARTICIPANT_ID" -i /tmp/identities.updated.json```

elements.text:
Everything worked. Thank you.

My idea about where the party was hosted was wrong which resulted in not being able do another recovery. I've got the correct participant id from API, used it as
id

in the identities dump and the recovery procedure worked.

Saving this for history

# Destroy validator (compose-based)
./stop.sh
 docker volume rm splice-validator_domain-upgrade-dump splice-validator_postgres-splice

# Update identities dump
SCAN_URL=

domain_id=global-domain::122071b3b1bdf69f2df3e161bd9933f2c419cdac3c48eaab7c2b920b6956d5d2a87b
party_id=stas-test-2025-05-09::122004320164ddaa20ea6d21e068d7884205ac762ed4dcd59bcc741259ac910af805
participant_id=$(curl -fsS "$SCAN_URL/api/scan/v0/domains/$domain_id/parties/$party_id/participant-id" | jq -r .participant_id)
cat /tmp/identities.json | jq --arg participant_id "$participant_id" '.id = $participant_id' > /tmp/identities.updated.json

# Recover
MIGRATION_ID=1
SPONSOR_SV_URL=
SEQUENCER_URL=

PARTY_HINT=stas-test-2025-05-09
NEW_PARTICIPANT_ID="$PARTY_HINT-8"
echo "Migrating $PARTY_HINT from $(echo "$participant_id" | awk -F :: '{print $2}') to $NEW_PARTICIPANT_ID"
./start.sh -s "$SPONSOR_SV_URL" -o "" -p "$PARTY_HINT" -m "$MIGRATION_ID" -w -bq "$SEQUENCER_URL" -P "$NEW_PARTICIPANT_ID" -i /tmp/identities.updated.json
